title: 111_hr106
content: The "American Opportunity Tax Credit Act of 2009" is a new section that provides a refundable credit for higher education expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The American Opportunity Tax Credit Act of 2009 allows a 100 percent credit for higher education expenses up to $4,000 for eligible students attending eligible educational institutions. The credit is limited to the individual's cost of attendance for the academic period. The American Opportunity Tax Credit Act of 2009 provides a 100 percent credit for higher education expenses up to $4,000 for eligible students at eligible educational institutions. The credit is limited to the individual's cost of attendance for the academic period, with a lifetime credit limitation of $28,000. An eligible student is defined as an individual who meets the requirements of section 484(a)(1) of the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term 'higher education expense' refers to any expense considered in determining the cost of attendance at an eligible educational institution for the taxpayer, spouse, or dependent. The term 'eligible educational institution' refers to an institution described in the Higher Education Act of 1965 and eligible to participate in a program under title IV of the same Act. No credit is allowed to a taxpayer for an eligible student unless the student's name and taxpayer identification number are included on the tax return. The tax for the taxable year can be adjusted for certain scholarships and educational assistance allowances under specific chapters of the United States Code. The tax for the taxable year can be adjusted for scholarships and educational assistance allowances related to a student's educational expenses at an eligible institution, which are excludable from gross income under US law. Coordination with section 25A reduces higher education expenses taken into account for an individual. If a deduction under section 151 is allowed to another taxpayer for a taxable year, expenses paid by a dependent are treated accordingly. No credit allowed under subsection (a) for an individual if a deduction is allowed to another taxpayer for the same taxable year. Higher education expenses paid by the individual may be treated as paid by the other taxpayer. Prepayments for academic periods starting within 3 months after the taxable year are considered paid during that year. No double benefit allowed. No double benefit allowed for the credit under this section if a deduction is allowed for the same expense. Married individuals must file a joint return for the credit to apply. Nonresident aliens can only claim the credit if they elect to be treated as a resident alien. Community service requirement is also specified. The community service requirement for claiming credit for higher education expenses mandates students to complete 100 hours of volunteer service for a governmental unit, hospital, or specified organization during the taxable year. Service must be verified by the Secretary of Education. The community service requirement for claiming credit for higher education expenses mandates students to complete 100 hours of volunteer service for a specified organization. An exception applies if the failure to meet the requirement is due to death or disability. Taxpayers can certify their belief in receiving credit directly to the educational institution. The taxpayer can elect not to apply this section to higher education expenses. The Secretary may issue regulations for recapturing credits in cases of refunds in subsequent years. The taxpayer can elect not to apply this section to higher education expenses. The Secretary may issue regulations for recapturing credits in cases of refunds in subsequent years. Conforming Amendments include changes to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. Effective December 31, 2009, higher education expenses are eligible for tax credits for education provided after that date.
